Real ID and how it will affect you.

Dear ##SM_RULE_360 Email Salutation##,

Back in 2005, Congress passed the Real ID Act imposing strict standards for driver's licenses in all states. For 13 years, the ACLU has fought this attempt at creating a national ID, and our advocacy drove the federal government to get rid of some of the most invasive aspects of the original plan. Now in 2018, a revised version of the Real ID Act is close to being fully implemented. And we still have major concerns.

We need to make sure that New Jersey creates a standard ID that isn't intended for federal purposes, and soon we'll be calling on you to contact your lawmakers. Prepare for what's coming by reading our FAQ.

The deadline for New Jersey to comply with the Real ID requirements is October 10, 2019, but it may come even sooner. Here's what you need to know:

  • The requirements to get a license for federal standards invade our privacy and they're not necessary for most New Jerseyans. Our default option needs to be a license intended for residents of New Jersey.
  • To get a driver's license for federal Real ID Act purposes, you'll need to hand over documentation verifying your full name, date of birth, address, and proof of Social Security number or valid immigration status.
  • The government will permanently keep scanned digital photocopies of your most sensitive documents, all together in electronic databases, jeopardizing our security and privacy.
  • Significant numbers of people — especially marginalized groups — may not be able to obtain these documents, much less produce them.
  • A driver's license shouldn't have to double as a national identity card. People need licenses to show they're qualified to drive. Using them for federal purposes is secondary.
LEARN MORE

New Jersey has an obligation to its people — especially those in marginalized groups — to make the basic license for state purposes the default option.

Have questions? Navigate to our FAQ for more information on how Real ID will affect you. And get ready to contact your legislators to demand a license that meets the needs of all New Jerseyans.

Thanks for sticking with us,

Amol Sinha
Executive Director, ACLU of New Jersey
